title: 1 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who did the LORD send to anoint Saul as king over Israel?
options: Samuel
David
Nathan
Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel
questions.explanation: Samuel was sent by the LORD to anoint Saul king over Israel as stated in 1 Samuel 15:1.

questions.question: What did the LORD command Saul to do to the Amalekites?
options: Utterly destroy all that they have
Make peace with them
Take them as servants
Ignore them
questions.correctAnswer: Utterly destroy all that they have
questions.explanation: The LORD commanded Saul to utterly destroy all that the Amalekites have, sparing nothing, as per 1 Samuel 15:3.

questions.question: How many footmen did Saul gather in Telaim?
questions.explanation: Saul gathered 200,000 footmen and 10,000 men of Judah in Telaim according to 1 Samuel 15:4.

questions.question: To whom did Saul tell to depart from among the Amalekites to avoid destruction?
options: Kenites
Judahites
Philistines
Canaanites
questions.correctAnswer: Kenites
questions.explanation: Saul told the Kenites to depart from among the Amalekites lest they be destroyed with them, as recorded in 1 Samuel 15:6.

questions.question: What did Saul and the people spare when they attacked the Amalekites?
options: Agag the king and the best of the livestock
Only the women and children
Nothing, they destroyed everything
Only the camels
questions.correctAnswer: Agag the king and the best of the livestock
questions.explanation: Saul and the people spared King Agag and the best sheep, oxen, fatlings, and lambs, which they should have destroyed, as shown in 1 Samuel 15:9.

questions.question: What was Samuel's response when he learned Saul had not fully obeyed the LORD?
options: He cried unto the LORD all night
He congratulated Saul
He ignored it
He immediately anointed another king
questions.correctAnswer: He cried unto the LORD all night
questions.explanation: Samuel was grieved and cried unto the LORD all night because Saul had not performed the LORD's commandments (1 Samuel 15:11).

questions.question: What excuse did Saul give for sparing the best of the animals?
options: To sacrifice them to the LORD
To feed the people
Because they were too young
He forgot to destroy them
questions.correctAnswer: To sacrifice them to the LORD
questions.explanation: Saul said the people spared the best animals to sacrifice to the LORD God, as explained in 1 Samuel 15:15.

questions.question: According to Samuel, what is better than sacrifice?
options: Obedience to the voice of the LORD
Many offerings
Wealth and riches
Great feasts
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to the voice of the LORD
questions.explanation: Samuel said obedience is better than sacrifice and to hearken than the fat of rams (1 Samuel 15:22).

questions.question: What did Samuel say rebellion is like?
options: The sin of witchcraft
A small mistake
A simple misunderstanding
A minor offense
questions.correctAnswer: The sin of witchcraft
questions.explanation: Samuel stated that rebellion is like the sin of witchcraft and stubbornness like iniquity and idolatry (1 Samuel 15:23).

questions.question: Who was taken alive by Saul but later killed by Samuel?
options: Agag
Saul
Samuel
David
questions.correctAnswer: Agag
questions.explanation: Saul took Agag, king of the Amalekites, alive, but Samuel later hewed Agag in pieces (1 Samuel 15:8, 33).

questions.question: True or False: Saul obeyed the LORD perfectly by destroying all the Amalekites and their possessions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Saul disobeyed the LORD by sparing King Agag and the best livestock, not utterly destroying all as commanded (1 Samuel 15:9).

questions.question: True or False: Samuel returned to Saul after their first meeting to worship the LORD together.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samuel turned again after Saul, and Saul worshipped the LORD (1 Samuel 15:31).

questions.question: True or False: The LORD repented that He had made Saul king over Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The LORD repented that He had made Saul king over Israel, as stated in 1 Samuel 15:35.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Samuel 15:28: 'The LORD hath rent the kingdom of Israel from thee this day, and hath given it to a ______ of thine, that is better than thou.'
options: neighbor
friend
brother
servant
questions.correctAnswer: neighbor
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:28 says the LORD gave the kingdom to a neighbor of Saul's who is better than him.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Samuel 15:24: 'I have sinned: for I have transgressed the commandment of the LORD, and thy words: because I feared the _______, and obeyed their voice.'
options: people
king
army
prophet
questions.correctAnswer: people
questions.explanation: Saul admitted he sinned because he feared the people and obeyed their voice (1 Samuel 15:24).

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's commands amid pressure from others. Based on 1 Samuel 15, what biblical truth would you share about obedience?
options: Obedience to God is more important than sacrifices or offerings
Sacrifices and offerings can replace obedience
Partial obedience is acceptable to God
Obedience is optional if it is difficult
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God is more important than sacrifices or offerings
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:22 teaches that obeying the voice of the LORD is better than sacrifice, highlighting that God values obedience over ritual offerings. This is supported by verses 1 Samuel 15:23 and 15:19, which stress the sinfulness of disobedience.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 15 teach about humility in leadership through Saul's example?
options: Leaders must recognize their calling and remain obedient to God
Leaders should rely on their own judgment over God's commands
Leaders are exempt from God's standards
Leaders should prioritize popularity over God's word
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must recognize their calling and remain obedient to God
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Samuel 15:1 and 15:17 show that Saul was anointed by God for leadership, but his failure to obey led to rejection (verses 15:10-11, 15:23). This teaches humility and submission to God's authority as essential for leaders.

questions.question: A believer fears the consequences of obeying God fully because of peer pressure. According to 1 Samuel 15, what consequence did Saul face for fearing the people's voice over God's command?
options: God rejected him as king
God increased his kingdom
He was praised for his wisdom
He was forgiven without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: God rejected him as king
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:24-26 shows Saul admitted sinning because he feared the people, and as a result, God rejected him from being king due to disobedience (15:23, 15:28).

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 15 reveal about God's nature regarding His promises and repentance?
options: God does not lie or repent like humans
God frequently changes His mind
God is uncertain in His decisions
God repents like humans do
questions.correctAnswer: God does not lie or repent like humans
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:29 states that the Strength of Israel (God) does not lie or repent because He is not a man, emphasizing God's faithfulness and unchanging nature.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 15 encourage believers to deal with temptation to compromise God's commands for convenience?
options: Complete obedience is required even when it is difficult
Partial obedience is acceptable if intentions are good
Compromise can be justified for peace
Ignoring God's commands is sometimes necessary
questions.correctAnswer: Complete obedience is required even when it is difficult
questions.explanation: Saul’s failure to fully obey God’s command to utterly destroy Amalek (verses 15:3, 15:9, 15:19) led to God's rejection (15:23). This shows that partial obedience is disobedience.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged after a failure in spiritual discipline. Based on 1 Samuel 15, what should they understand about God's response to disobedience and repentance?
options: God grieves over disobedience but calls for repentance
God immediately removes all blessings with no chance to repent
God ignores repentance if failure happens
God rewards failure as long as intentions are good
questions.correctAnswer: God grieves over disobedience but calls for repentance
questions.explanation: Verses 1 Samuel 15:11 and 15:24 show that God and Samuel grieved over Saul’s disobedience, yet Saul was encouraged to ask for pardon and turn back (15:25, 15:30-31).

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 15, what does this passage teach about integrity in daily life and work?
options: Completing tasks with full obedience to God is essential
Taking the best for oneself is acceptable if justified
Partial completion of duties is sufficient
Ignoring God’s instructions for personal gain is wise
questions.correctAnswer: Completing tasks with full obedience to God is essential
questions.explanation: Saul spared the best of the Amalekite spoil (1 Samuel 15:9, 15:21), disobeying God's command to utterly destroy all, showing lack of integrity and resulting in rejection (15:23).

questions.question: True or False: 1 Samuel 15 teaches that God’s commands should be followed even when it requires sacrifice and is difficult.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes complete obedience (verses 15:3, 15:22) over sacrifice or convenience, showing that God values obedience above all.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 15, Saul was forgiven and restored to full favor after asking Samuel for pardon.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Although Saul asked for pardon (15:24-25, 15:30-31), Samuel told him God rejected him as king (15:26, 15:28), indicating no full restoration.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Samuel declared, 'To obey is better than ________, and to hearken than the fat of rams.'
options: sacrifice
offering
prayer
giving
questions.correctAnswer: sacrifice
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:22 states that obedience is better than sacrifice, highlighting the priority of obeying God's commands over ritual offerings.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 15 teach about the importance of trust in God rather than relying on human wisdom?
options: Trusting God's command leads to obedience and blessing
Human wisdom should override God's commands
Trust in people is more important than God's word
Ignoring God's instructions is wise when convenient
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God's command leads to obedience and blessing
questions.explanation: Saul’s failure to fully trust and obey God (verses 15:19, 15:24) resulted in rejection, showing that reliance on God’s word is crucial.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 15 teach about prayer and seeking God when we face spiritual failure?
options: Prayer is essential for seeking God's help and forgiveness
Prayer is unnecessary if failure occurs
Prayer can replace obedience
Prayer is only for good times
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is essential for seeking God's help and forgiveness
questions.explanation: Samuel prayed all night after hearing of Saul's disobedience (15:11), and Saul also sought pardon through prayer (15:24-25), showing prayer's importance in repentance.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 15 reveal the consequences of stubbornness and rebellion against God?
options: It leads to rejection and loss of position
It is excusable if done out of fear
It brings honor from God
It results in immediate forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to rejection and loss of position
questions.explanation: Verses 15:23 and 15:26 show that rebellion and stubbornness led to Saul’s rejection by God and loss of kingship.

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 15, what biblical principle can be taught about humility and contentment in God's plan?
options: Accepting God's will even when it means losing worldly status
Demanding one's own way regardless of God's plan
Complaining about God's decisions
Ignoring God's plan for personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: Accepting God's will even when it means losing worldly status
questions.explanation: Saul experienced loss of kingdom (15:28) but Samuel mourned for him (15:35), showing the importance of humbly accepting God’s will.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 15 encourage believers to reflect on their stewardship and generosity?
options: God expects full obedience and stewardship without selfish gain
Taking the best for oneself is acceptable stewardship
Stewardship can be partial when convenient
Generosity is optional if others pressure you
questions.correctAnswer: God expects full obedience and stewardship without selfish gain
questions.explanation: Saul spared the best spoil for himself and sacrifices (15:9, 15:21), disobeying God’s command to destroy all, showing failure in stewardship and obedience.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 15.

questions.question: What was the primary command God gave Saul through Samuel regarding the Amalekites?
options: To utterly destroy all that they have, sparing no one
To make peace with the Amalekites
To take Agag alive and make him a servant
To capture only the livestock and spare the people
questions.correctAnswer: To utterly destroy all that they have, sparing no one
questions.explanation: God commanded Saul to smite Amalek and utterly destroy all that they have, sparing no one, including men, women, infants, and animals (1 Samuel 15:3).

questions.question: How does the episode of Saul sparing Agag and the best animals foreshadow later biblical themes?
options: It highlights the theme of incomplete obedience leading to judgment
It shows God's acceptance of animal sacrifice over obedience
It predicts the rise of the Amalekite kingdom
It anticipates the restoration of Saul's kingship
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the theme of incomplete obedience leading to judgment
questions.explanation: Saul’s disobedience by sparing Agag and the best animals illustrates the biblical theme that partial obedience to God's commands leads to divine judgment (1 Samuel 15:9, 23).

questions.question: What reason did Saul give for sparing the best of the livestock?
options: To sacrifice them to the LORD thy God
Because they were too valuable to destroy
He forgot to kill them
The people took them secretly
questions.correctAnswer: To sacrifice them to the LORD thy God
questions.explanation: Saul explained to Samuel that the people spared the best animals to sacrifice to the LORD, although this was disobedient to God's command (1 Samuel 15:15, 21).

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel's statement, 'To obey is better than sacrifice' in the context of Israelite worship?
options: It emphasizes the priority of obedience over ritual sacrifice
It suggests sacrifices are unnecessary
It means sacrifices replace obedience
It refers to sacrifices being more important than obedience
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the priority of obedience over ritual sacrifice
questions.explanation: Samuel stresses that God values obedience more than burnt offerings, indicating that ritual without obedience is insufficient (1 Samuel 15:22).

questions.question: What literary device is demonstrated by Samuel tearing his mantle when he leaves Saul?
options: Symbolism signifying the kingdom being torn from Saul
Foreshadowing Saul's military victory
Hyperbole to show Samuel's anger
Metaphor for Saul’s future prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolism signifying the kingdom being torn from Saul
questions.explanation: The tearing of Samuel's mantle symbolically represents God's rejection of Saul's kingship and the kingdom being taken from him (1 Samuel 15:27-28).

questions.question: How does the rejection of Saul as king relate to the broader biblical theme of covenant faithfulness?
options: Saul’s failure to obey God reflects breaking the covenant, leading to rejection
Saul's rejection is unrelated to covenant faithfulness
God rejects Saul because of external political pressure
It demonstrates divine favoritism toward other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Saul’s failure to obey God reflects breaking the covenant, leading to rejection
questions.explanation: Saul’s disobedience is portrayed as rebellion against God's covenant, resulting in his rejection as king, consistent with the theme that covenant faithfulness is essential in Israel’s leadership (1 Samuel 15:23, 26, 28).

questions.question: Which tribe contributed 10,000 men to Saul’s army according to the chapter?
options: Judah
Benjamin
Ephraim
Levi
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: The text states that Saul gathered two hundred thousand footmen and ten thousand men from the tribe of Judah (1 Samuel 15:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of Saul warning the Kenites to depart from among the Amalekites?
options: Because the Kenites had shown kindness to Israel when they came from Egypt
Because the Kenites were allied with the Amalekites
Because the Kenites were enemies of Israel
Because the Kenites were spies for the Amalekites
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Kenites had shown kindness to Israel when they came from Egypt
questions.explanation: Saul spared the Kenites due to their kindness to Israel during the Exodus, telling them to depart to avoid destruction (1 Samuel 15:6).

questions.question: True or False: Samuel mourned for Saul even after God rejected him as king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samuel mourned for Saul despite God's rejection of him as king, showing the prophet’s personal grief (1 Samuel 15:35).

questions.question: What does Samuel’s execution of King Agag symbolize in the narrative?
options: Divine justice for Amalek’s past cruelty
Samuel’s personal vengeance
A political alliance with Amalek
A ritual sacrifice to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Divine justice for Amalek’s past cruelty
questions.explanation: Samuel’s killing of Agag symbolizes divine justice as Amalek had made women childless, and now Agag's mother will be childless (1 Samuel 15:33).

questions.question: How does the phrase 'The Strength of Israel will not lie nor repent' relate to God's nature in contrast to human leaders?
options: It emphasizes God's unchanging faithfulness unlike fallible humans like Saul
It suggests God is as fallible as humans
It means God changes his mind frequently
It implies human leaders are stronger than God
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's unchanging faithfulness unlike fallible humans like Saul
questions.explanation: This phrase highlights the divine attribute of unchanging truth and faithfulness, contrasting with human weakness and failure (1 Samuel 15:29).

questions.question: Which location did Saul go to after the battle, where he set up a place and then went to Gilgal?
options: Carmel
Ramah
Gibeah
Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Carmel
questions.explanation: The text says Saul came to Carmel, where he set up a place, then passed on to Gilgal (1 Samuel 15:12).

questions.question: What reason does Saul give for his disobedience to God’s command?
options: He feared the people and obeyed their voice
He did not hear the command clearly
He sought to protect his own life
He wanted to make an alliance with Amalek
questions.correctAnswer: He feared the people and obeyed their voice
questions.explanation: Saul admits to sinning because he feared the people and obeyed their voice instead of God’s command (1 Samuel 15:24).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'rebellion is as the sin of witchcraft' in Israelite culture?
options: It equates disobedience to God with severe spiritual corruption
It means rebellion is a minor offense
It refers to rebellion being a common practice
It shows that witchcraft was tolerated
questions.correctAnswer: It equates disobedience to God with severe spiritual corruption
questions.explanation: The phrase portrays rebellion as a serious sin comparable to witchcraft, emphasizing the gravity of disobedience (1 Samuel 15:23).

questions.question: True or False: After Saul's rejection, Samuel never saw him again until the day of Saul's death.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samuel did not come to see Saul again after this incident until the day of his death (1 Samuel 15:35).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God 'repenting' that He made Saul king, as noted in this chapter?
options: It anthropomorphizes God to express divine regret over human failure
It means God changes His mind like humans
It shows God never intended Saul to be king
It suggests God is fallible
questions.correctAnswer: It anthropomorphizes God to express divine regret over human failure
questions.explanation: The language of God 'repenting' is a biblical anthropomorphism expressing divine sorrow over Saul's disobedience and failure (1 Samuel 15:11, 35).

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary command God gave to Saul through Samuel regarding the Amalekites?
options: Utterly destroy all that they had without sparing any
Make peace treaties with them
Take Agag as a captive and keep their livestock
Ignore the Amalekites and focus on other enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Utterly destroy all that they had without sparing any
questions.explanation: God commanded Saul to utterly destroy Amalek, sparing nothing, including men, women, infants, and animals (1 Samuel 15:3). This reflects God's holiness and justice in judgment (Deuteronomy 25:17-19; Exodus 17:8-16; Judges 3:1-4; Romans 12:19).

questions.question: How did Saul respond to God's command concerning the Amalekites?
options: He spared King Agag and the best of the livestock
He completely obeyed and destroyed all
He fled from battle and did not confront Amalek
He made a treaty with the Amalekites
questions.correctAnswer: He spared King Agag and the best of the livestock
questions.explanation: Saul disobeyed by sparing King Agag and the best animals, which represented partial obedience and rebellion against God's command (1 Samuel 15:9). God's judgment requires full obedience (Joshua 7:11-12; 1 Kings 21:19; Hebrews 10:26).

questions.question: What reason did Saul give for sparing the best of the livestock?
options: To sacrifice them to the LORD
He wanted to keep them for his own use
He was afraid of Amalekite retaliation
He forgot God's command
questions.correctAnswer: To sacrifice them to the LORD
questions.explanation: Saul claimed the best animals were spared to sacrifice to God, but this was disobedience disguised as piety (1 Samuel 15:15). God values obedience over sacrifice (1 Samuel 15:22; Psalm 51:16-17; Hosea 6:6; Matthew 9:13).

questions.question: What does Samuel say is better than sacrifice in God's sight?
options: Obedience to the voice of the LORD
Offering many burnt offerings
Giving abundant tithes
Performing great miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to the voice of the LORD
questions.explanation: Samuel emphasizes that obedience is superior to sacrifice (1 Samuel 15:22), underscoring God's desire for faithful heart commitment rather than ritualistic offerings (1 Samuel 15:22; Micah 6:6-8; Proverbs 21:3; Romans 12:1).

questions.question: What consequence did Samuel pronounce on Saul for his rebellion?
options: The LORD has rejected Saul as king over Israel
Saul would reign for many more years
He would receive a second chance to obey
He would be forgiven without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has rejected Saul as king over Israel
questions.explanation: Samuel declares that because Saul rejected God's word, God has rejected him from being king (1 Samuel 15:23, 26, 28). This shows divine sovereignty and holiness in leadership (Psalm 89:27-28; Isaiah 55:8-9; Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'rebellion is as the sin of witchcraft' imply about sin in God's eyes?
options: Rebellion is a grave spiritual offense akin to idolatry
Rebellion is a minor mistake
Rebellion is unrelated to sin
Rebellion is acceptable if done with good intentions
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion is a grave spiritual offense akin to idolatry
questions.explanation: Samuel's statement equates rebellion with witchcraft and stubbornness with idolatry, highlighting sin as deliberate opposition to God's authority (1 Samuel 15:23). This aligns with biblical teaching on the seriousness of willful sin (1 Samuel 15:23; 1 John 3:4; Romans 1:21-32; Isaiah 1:2-4).

questions.question: What does Saul's confession reveal about his failure?
options: He feared the people and obeyed their voice instead of God's
He was unaware of God's command
He sought God's guidance but was misled
He deliberately planned to disobey God
questions.correctAnswer: He feared the people and obeyed their voice instead of God's
questions.explanation: Saul admits his sin was motivated by fear of the people and yielding to their voice over God's command (1 Samuel 15:24). This illustrates human weakness and the danger of partial obedience (Exodus 23:2; Proverbs 29:25; James 4:7; Psalm 118:8).

questions.question: How does the LORD describe Himself in relation to lying and repenting in this chapter?
options: The Strength of Israel will not lie nor repent because He is not a man
God often changes His mind
God sometimes lies to test His people
God is like humans and repents frequently
questions.correctAnswer: The Strength of Israel will not lie nor repent because He is not a man
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:29 describes God's immutable nature, affirming He is truthful and unchanging, contrasting with human fallibility (Numbers 23:19; Malachi 3:6; Hebrews 6:17-18; James 1:17).

questions.question: What does the cutting of Samuel's mantle signify when Saul tries to detain him?
options: The LORD has torn the kingdom from Saul and given it to a better neighbor
Samuel wants Saul to stay as king
Saul is forgiven and restored
It represents Samuel's personal anger
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has torn the kingdom from Saul and given it to a better neighbor
questions.explanation: Samuel's mantle tearing symbolizes God's judgment in removing Saul's kingship and transferring it to a better leader (1 Samuel 15:27-28). This typifies divine sovereignty and the consequences of disobedience (2 Samuel 1:10; Isaiah 22:21; Jeremiah 1:10; Ezekiel 21:26-27).

questions.question: What was Samuel's final act towards King Agag, and what does it signify?
options: Samuel executed Agag, signifying divine justice for Amalek's sin
Samuel spared Agag to show mercy
Samuel sent Agag into exile
Samuel imprisoned Agag for life
questions.correctAnswer: Samuel executed Agag, signifying divine justice for Amalek's sin
questions.explanation: Samuel personally put Agag to death (1 Samuel 15:33), symbolizing the fulfillment of God's judgment against Amalek for their opposition to Israel (Exodus 17:14; Deuteronomy 25:17-19; Numbers 24:20; Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What does the LORD's regret over making Saul king reveal about God's sovereignty and human responsibility?
options: God's regret shows His sorrow over human disobedience but does not negate His sovereignty
God is unsure and changes His mind often
God abandons His plans completely
God punishes the innocent because of failure
questions.correctAnswer: God's regret shows His sorrow over human disobedience but does not negate His sovereignty
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 15:11 and 35 show God regretting making Saul king, indicating God's relational nature and justice while maintaining His ultimate sovereign plan (Genesis 6:6; Exodus 32:14; Jonah 3:10; Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What theological lesson about worship and obedience is conveyed in Saul's attempt to worship after sinning?
options: True worship requires obedience, not just ritual or presence
Worship can erase sin without repentance
God accepts worship regardless of obedience
Worship is independent of moral conduct
questions.correctAnswer: True worship requires obedience, not just ritual or presence
questions.explanation: Saul's worship after sinning (1 Samuel 15:30-31) shows that God desires heartfelt obedience over mere ritual acts. This aligns with scriptures emphasizing obedience as integral to worship (Isaiah 1:11-17; Micah 6:6-8; John 4:23-24; Hebrews 10:22-25).

questions.question: What does the sparing of Agag and the best animals by Saul demonstrate about the nature of sin and partial obedience?
options: Partial obedience is disobedience and displeases God
Partial obedience is acceptable if done for religious reasons
Selective obedience is better than complete obedience
God values mercy over obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Partial obedience is disobedience and displeases God
questions.explanation: Saul's partial obedience (1 Samuel 15:9) displeased God and led to his rejection. Scripture teaches that incomplete obedience is rebellion (1 Samuel 15:22-23; James 2:10; Luke 11:28; Proverbs 28:9).

questions.question: How does this chapter contribute to the biblical understanding of God's holiness and justice?
options: God demands complete obedience and punishes sin to maintain holiness
God overlooks sin for the sake of mercy
God ignores human disobedience
God accepts any form of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: God demands complete obedience and punishes sin to maintain holiness
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God's holiness requiring full compliance (1 Samuel 15:3, 23) and His justice in punishing disobedience (Romans 1:18; Isaiah 6:3; Hebrews 12:29; Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: What eschatological or messianic theme can be drawn from God's rejection of Saul as king?
options: God's rejection paves the way for a perfect, eternal King from David's line
It indicates the end of all kingship
It shows that monarchy is flawed and rejected by God
It implies God will never appoint another king
questions.correctAnswer: God's rejection paves the way for a perfect, eternal King from David's line
questions.explanation: Saul's rejection (1 Samuel 15:28) sets the stage for David, the anointed king foreshadowing Christ, the eternal King (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Isaiah 9:6-7; Luke 1:32-33; Hebrews 1:8).
